) Purpose: This Revenue Officer legal reference guide discusses the different legal theories and methods of collection from third parties. (

) Audience: This IRM is used by Collection employees developing and gating cases where third party liabilities become an important factor for administrative and judicial collection. Primarily Collection Advisory staff or Collection Revenue Officers use this IRM when pursuing or assisting and the Department of Justice with affirmative judicial actions. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy SBSE. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy, SBSE, Enforcement is the program of this IRM. (

) Primary Stakeholders: Field Collection, Advisory, and Chief Counsel. Other areas that are affected by these procedures or have input to the procedures include Appeals, the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS), and Department of Justice Attorneys. (

) Program Goals: Taxpayers sometimes try to thwart the collection of their li- abilities by disguising and/or transferring property ownership. This Legal Reference Guide positions the Revenue Officer to identify and defeat these deceptions. In this IRM is a working knowledge of the third-party legal mentals that, when applied, may result in collecting the taxpayer’s liability through a third party. Revenue Officers and Advisors use these to recognize the applicable theory and initiate appropriate action. (

) This section provides guidance on the methods the United States can use to collect an unpaid liability where an initially liable person, e.g., a taxpayer “transferor”), has transferred property to a third party (the “transferee”) prior or after the liability to the United States is incurred. However, it is not the source of procedural instructions. Revenue Officers and other Internal Service personnel must still look to the procedural Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) provisions outside this Handbook for such instructions. (

They will be required to prepare reports concerning any facts ascertained. The reviewers, approvers, and lawyers charged with the responsibility of handling the cases must rely on those facts and reports when making case decisions. (

Using IRC 6901 and a substantive provision of the law to assert liability against the transferee allows the IRS to collect through administrative or judicial remedies. The liability of the transferee is secondary to that of the transferor similar to a trust fund liability’s relationship to the underlying corporate liability. Meaning the transferee liability is derived from the transferor’s liability. It does not create a new liability.

Using litigation and a substantive provision of the law to establish a transferee liability creates a judgment against the transferee for the amount determined by the court. If the abstract of judgment is ﬁled, it creates a judgment lien. The judgment does not merge with the transferor’s liability. The judgment lien does not merge with the transferor’s federal tax lien nor does it create a federal tax lien against the transferee. Collection is judicial only.
